introducao: Bem-vindo à Lesson 5. Hoje você vai aprender o modo imperativo, preposições, capitais, roupas e expressões de quantidade.

Lesson5.text: imperative
O modo imperativo é usado para dar ordens ou instruções, como 'Take!', 'Put!', 'Open!' e 'Close!'.
Take the book, please.
Open the book, please.
Close the book, please.
Vamos ver ações com ele e ela.
What’s he or she doing?
Usamos 'What’s he doing?' ou 'What’s she doing?' para perguntar o que alguém está fazendo.
He’s taking the book.
She’s opening the book.
He’s putting the book on the table.
Muito bem, próxima parte.
here and there
‘Here’ significa aqui e ‘there’ significa lá. Observe os exemplos.
Where’s the black pencil? The black pencil’s here in front of me.
Where’s the white pencil? The white pencil’s there on the wall.
Are you sitting there? No, I’m not sitting there; I’m sitting here.
Vamos continuar.
capital and countries
Vamos aprender nomes de países e suas capitais.
What’s the capital of England? London’s the capital of England.
What’s the capital of Russia? Moscow’s the capital of Russia.
What’s the capital of Greece? Athens’s the capital of Greece.
What’s the capital of China? Beijing’s the capital of China.
Próximo tema.
reading and writing
‘Reading’ significa lendo e ‘writing’ significa escrevendo. Vamos praticar.
What am I doing? You’re reading the book.
What am I doing? You’re writing in the book.
Am I writing in the book? No, you’re not writing; you’re reading.
Am I reading the book? No, you’re not reading; you’re writing.
Muito bem, próxima seção.
clothes and accessories
Vamos aprender nomes de roupas e acessórios comuns.
This is a coat, dress, or skirt.
These are tights and scarves.
These are blouses, pockets, and handkerchiefs.
Seguindo.
how many
‘How many’ é usado para perguntar 'quantos' ou 'quantas' de algo.
How many pictures are there on these walls? There are pictures on these walls.
How many clocks are there in this room? There’s one clock in this room.
How many teachers are there in this room? There’s one teacher in this room.
Agora vamos aprender uma expressão comum com o verbo go.
going to
‘Going to’ significa 'indo para' e é usado para expressar movimento.
What am I doing? You’re going to the door.
What am I doing? You’re going to the window.
Where am I going? You’re going to the wall.
Am I going to the door? No, you aren’t going to the door; you’re going to the window.
Parabéns! Você concluiu a Lesson 5.
